repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, a highly likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts. Lessons learned suggest
            the following. The provision of timely and sufficient
            technical assistance (TA) was part of the strategy for the
            financial sector reform program, which was instrumental in
            supporting the project preparation and implementation,
            whose. The early availability of these resources facilitated
            the design of an operation with strong up-front
            conditionality, and, also served to reinforce the
            Government's commitment to the program. The attention
            paid to project design led to development of a challenging
            program with realistic outcomes, focusing the program on
            capacity building and implementation. This focus also proved
            helpful in keeping the reform program on track, as it
            facilitated good measurement of achievements over time.
            Moreover, although synergies can be realized by involving
            other members of the Bank Group, extra care needs to be
            taken in project design to avoid real and perceived
            conflicts of interest: while retaining the Insurance
            Institute of Albania (INSIG) in the program was important
            for the overall development of the financial sector, the
            Bank's options in pursuing conditionality related to
            INSIG were limited, as a potential conflict of interest
            could have resulted from IFC's eventual privatization investment.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project - release of the second tranche - full compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Adjustment Credit
            Project (FSAC) continues the support to Albania's
            financial sector reforms as elaborated in the Growth and
            Poverty Reduction Strategy. Designed to support the
            implementation of the final phase of the State's
            divestiture from the financial sector, and to change the
            State's role from an owner to a regulator, the project
            supports this transition by improvements to the legal and
            institutional framework, necessary for functioning of a
            market based financial sector, and so critical for
            sustaining the long-term impact of the structural reforms
            and growth. In view of the overall performance and progress
            with the implementation of the program supported by the
            Credit, and in full compliance with the specific conditions
            of release as described in Section 2.02 (d) and Schedule 2
            of the Development Credit Agreement (DCA), the second
            tranche is released.

5085534.trustfund:
TF039326-ALBANIA - BANKING PRIVATIZATION PROJECT,TF025577-PHRD-FINANCIAL SECTOR
            ADJUSTMENT CREDIT,TF040098-ALBANIA-ASSISTANCE TO THE

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Adjustment Credit
            Project will support the Government of Albania's
            program on consolidation, and reform implementation in the
            financial sector, beyond achievements to date, to foster
            improved engagement of the financial sector in its economic
            development. The project's three main components will:
            1) continue reforms in the banking sector, including the
            privatization of the Savings Bank (SvB), and further
            strengthening of the banking regulation and supervision
            systems; 2) consolidate, and strengthen the bankruptcy, and
            debt resolution framework; and, 3) foster reform
            implementation of the non-bank financial sector, including
            the development of the regulatory, and supervisory framework
            for the insurance development, and privatization of the
            Insurance Institute of Albania (INSIG). While project
            benefits will far outweigh risks, these remain, namely
            political, macroeconomic, and capacity constraints. To
            mitigate such risks, key legislation will be passed prior to
            Board presentation; steps are being taken under different
            operations to address the country's energy crisis; in
            addition, the International Finance Corporation has agreed
            to proceed with a pre-privatization investment in INSIG,
            while SvB's privatization is already advanced, which
            minimizes financial risks. And, while capacity building
            should not be underestimated, substantial technical
            assistance is being provided to minimize this risk.
